raw_text: Schone and Jurafsky (2001) employ a great many sophisticated post-hoc adjustments to obtain the right conflation sets for words by pure corpus analysis without annotations
clean_text: Schone and Jurafsky (2001) employ a great many sophisticated post-hoc adjustments to obtain the right conflation sets for words by pure corpus analysis without annotations.

citing_paper_authors: Damir, Ćavar | Joshua, Herring | Toshikazu, Ikuta | Paul, Rodrigues | Giancarlo, Schrementi
raw_text: Approaches to the induction of morphology as presented in e.g. Schone and Jurafsky (2001) or Goldsmith (2001) show that the morphological 1 See Batchelder (1998) for a discussion of these
clean_text: Approaches to the induction of morphology as presented in e.g. Schone and Jurafsky (2001) or Goldsmith (2001) show that the morphological properties of a small subset of languages can be induced with high accuracy, most of the existing approaches are motivated by applied or engineering concerns, and thus make assumptions that are less cognitively plausible.

citing_paper_authors: Damir, Ćavar | Joshua, Herring | Toshikazu, Ikuta | Paul, Rodrigues | Giancarlo, Schrementi
raw_text: Just to mention such approaches: Grimshaw (1981), and Pinker (1984) made in various approaches ,e.g. Mintz (1996) selects a small set of all words, the most frequent words, to induce word types via clustering; Schone and Jurafsky (2001) select words with frequency higher than 5 to induce morphological segmentation
clean_text: Schone and Jurafsky (2001) select words with frequency higher than 5 to induce morphological segmentation.

citing_paper_authors: Damir, Ćavar | Joshua, Herring | Toshikazu, Ikuta | Paul, Rodrigues | Giancarlo, Schrementi
raw_text: Presupposing input driven learning, it has been shown in the literature that initial segmenations into words (or word-like units) is possible with unsupervised methods (e.g. Brent and Cartwright (1996)), that induction of morphology is possible (e.g. Goldsmith (2001), Schone and Jurafsky (2001)) and even the induction of syntactic structures (e.g. Van Zaanen (2001))
clean_text: Presupposing input driven learning, it has been shown in the literature that initial segmenations into words (or word-like units) is possible with unsupervised methods (e.g. Brent and Cartwright (1996)), that induction of morphology is possible (e.g. Goldsmith (2001), Schone and Jurafsky (2001)) and even the induction of syntactic structures (e.g. Van Zaanen (2001)).

raw_text: These models include the signature of (Goldsmith 2001), the conflation set of (Schone and Jurafsky 2001), the paradigm of (Brent et. al. 2002), and the inflectional class of (Monson 2004)
clean_text: These models include the signature of (Goldsmith 2001), the conflation set of (Schone and Jurafsky 2001), the paradigm of (Brent et. al. 2002), and the inflectional class of (Monson 2004).

clean_text: In later work, Schone and Jurafsky (2001) extend their technique to identify not only suffixes but also prefixes and circumfixes by building both forward and backward tries over a corpus.

clean_text: Schone and Jurafsky (2001) use latent semantic analysis to find prefixes, suffixes and circumfixes in German, Dutch and English.

citing_paper_authors: Young-Suk, Lee | Kishore, Papineni | Salim, Roukos | Ossama, Emam | Hany, Hassan
raw_text: (Goldsmith 2000) presents an unsupervised technique based on the expectation maximization algorithm and minimum description length to segment exactly one suffix per word, resulting in an F-score of 81.8 for suffix identification in English according to (Schone and Jurafsky 2001)
clean_text: (Goldsmith 2000) presents an unsupervised technique based on the expectation maximization algorithm and minimum description length to segment exactly one suffix per word, resulting in an F-score of 81.8 for suffix identification in English according to (Schone and Jurafsky 2001).

raw_text: (Schone and Jurafsky 2001) proposes an unsupervised algorithm capable of automatically inducing the morphology of inflectional languages using only text corpora
clean_text: (Schone and Jurafsky 2001) proposes an unsupervised algorithm capable of automatically inducing the morphology of inflectional languages using only text corpora.

clean_text: Often trie similarities are used as a first step followed by further processing to identify morphemes (Schone and Jurafsky, 2001).

citing_paper_authors: Taesun, Moon | Katrin, Erk | Jason, Baldridge
raw_text: Yet, many studies have evaluated their segmentations and clusters by going over their results word by word, cluster by cluster and judging by sight whether some segmentation or clustering is good (e.g., Goldsmith (2001)) .Like Schone and Jurafsky (2001), we build clusters that will have both inflectionally and derivation ally related stems and evaluate them with respect to a gold standard of only inflectionally re lated stems
clean_text: Like Schone and Jurafsky (2001), we build clusters that will have both inflectionally and derivationally related stems and evaluate them with respect to a gold standard of only inflectionally related stems.

citing_paper_authors: Taesun, Moon | Katrin, Erk | Jason, Baldridge
raw_text: Schone and Jurafsky (2001) builds on this approach, but adds more ad hoc parameters to handle circumfixation
clean_text: Schone and Jurafsky (2001) builds on this approach, but adds more ad hoc parameters to handle circumfixation.

raw_text: Further cues for morphological learning are presented in (Schone and Jurafsky, 2001) and (Yarowsky and Wicentowsky, 2000)
clean_text: Further cues for morphological learning are presented in (Schone and Jurafsky, 2001) and (Yarowsky and Wicentowsky, 2000).

raw_text: A somewhat tighter definition of co-occurrence, which nevertheless yields a semantic distance measure, serves as the basis ofa method that captures irregular inflectional trans formations in Yarowsky and Wicentowski (2001) .1 Schone and Jurafsky (2001) employ distributions over adjacent words (yielding a syntactic distance metric) to improve the precision of their conflation sets. In contrast with these approaches, ours is predicated on a strictly local notion of co-occurrence
clean_text: Schone and Jurafsky (2001) employ distributions over adjacent words (yielding a syntactic distance metric) to improve the precision of their conflation sets.

raw_text: In addition, we measure precision, recall ,andF1 as in Schone and Jurafsky (2001)
clean_text: In addition, we measure precision, recall, and F1 as in Schone and Jurafsky (2001).

raw_text: Nevertheless, these metrics give us a point of comparison with Schone and Jurafsky (2001) who, using a vocabulary of Englishwords occurring at least 10 times in a 6.7 million word newswire corpus, report F1 of 88.1 for con 133flation sets based only on suffixation, and 84.5 for circumfixation
clean_text: Nevertheless, these metrics give us a point of comparison with Schone and Jurafsky (2001) who, using a vocabulary of English words occurring at least 10 times in a 6.7 million word newswire corpus, report F1 of 88.1 for conflation sets based only on suffixation, and 84.5 for circumfixation.
